posts.author: flaeske321
posts.content:
Hi guys,

Can you help me with a build?

I'm gonna play the Official campaign and i want to play a melee cleric build with 15 levels in the cleric class.

I don't know which classes i should focus on for the last 5 levels? Monk/Fighter/Rogue/Champion of Torm?

Thanks in advantage :)

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Do you want to stop at the end of the OC, or continue into Aribeth's Redemption (which takes you to level 26 or so), or Mines of Twin Summit (which takes you all the way to level 40, but might not be best with a caster because of how resting works)?

I am curious. Why did you choose specifically 15 levels of Cleric?

For a level 20 build with 15 levels of Cleric, I recommend Cleric 15 / Fighter 2 / Rogue 3, but the OC will only take you to level 18, and the 18th level is not guaranteed. For a Cleric for the OC with the number of Cleric levels unspecified, I would play a Cleric 18 / Fighter 2.

posts.author: flaeske321
posts.content:
So far i'm planning to stop at the end of OC.
Is Aribeth's Redemption any good and compatible with NWN EE?

Buffs like Magic Vestments, Greater Magic Weapon, Divine Favor..etc are capped at 15.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
In  theory, EE should be backwards compatible Aribeth's Redemption, but in practice, incompatibilities have cropped for various modules.

I have enjoyed it several times now, so I recommend it. It is a love story between your PC and Aribeth, so you need to be male, a Human, Elf, or Half-Elf, and you need to be as close to Lawful Good as possible. Chaotic Good works, though. There is a lot of dialog at the beginning for the trial and to set up the story, but after that, there is a lot of action, not boring at all.

Unless I misinterpreted what I was told, the old trick of using Divine Power to get your 4th attack at full AB has been patched out in EE. I propose to make you a level 28 build for the OC plus Aribeth's Redemption which will also work for the OC by itself. At level 18, where the OC ends, he will be Cleric 16 / Fighter 2, with the 16th level of Cleric giving you a couple more spells per day. At level 20, Cleric 16 / Fighter 4 with Weapon Spec and 4 attacks per round without a spell needed to grant it, and at level 28, Cleric 20  / Fighter 8, for maximum spells-per-day and 2 more Fighter feats. How does that sound?

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
flaeske321 wrote: I'm thinking about this build: Cleric 20 / Fighter 6 / Shadowdancer 2 to get HiPS, Evasion and more Tumble points. What do you think?
Oh, you want to be stealthy? That is completely different from the STR-based build I had in mind, but doable. However, without Sneak Attack, I don't think stealth would help you in any way, except to help you escape if you get in trouble. To get SD, you would sacrifice 2 feats for Dodge and Mobility (requiring more DEX than I had planned), and cross-train a lot of points into Hide and Move Silently. If Tumble is the main reason for adding SD, then how about Cleric 17 / Fighter 6 / Rogue 5?

posts.author: flaeske321
posts.content: What do you guys think is strongest? A Cleric/Monk dex based dual-wielding build or str based Cleric/Bard/RDD like "Blood and Faith"?

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Since EE nerfs Divine Power and you only have 28 levels to play with, I would choose Cleric 17 / Monk 5 / Fighter 6 over a Cleric/ Bard RDD. If you want to dual-wield your kamas, you will have to sacrifice 3 feats. but even single-wielding, you still will get 6 attacks, plus one from Haste and one from Flurry of Blows. Also, you would have to wear Monk robes and no shield, or you will lose a lot of the Monk goodies.

posts.content:
Sounds good :)

In what order should i level up each classes?

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
I suggest Monk at levels 2, 7, 12, 17, and 22, for Tumble skill dumps. You'll want to keep the Fighter levels even with Monk levels, never more than 1 apart to avoid an experience penalty. You need to have Cleric 12 / Monk 4 / Fighter 4 at level 20 for the best AB. Also, as often as possible, try to take each non-Cleric level after an odd-numbered Cleric level so you can get the next level of spells first.

It is much easier for me to show you than to describe it all, so here is the build:

Since you shouldn't be casting in combat, you might consider moving all skill points from Concentration to somewhere else, like Heal or Lore.

Instead of just playing the build, you could learn some things about building by studying the build a figuring out why I put what I put where I put it. I hesitated to use the word "study" because I do not assume that this is the textbook example of the best possible build, but then I couldn't come up with a suitable substitute word to use instead. If any decision I made doean't make sense to you, ask and I'll explain. You might even have a valid point that will make me change my mind.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Doh! I totally goofed by leaving out Weapon Finesse!

Substituting CoT for Fighter costs you Weapon Spec / Epic Weapon Spec, for 6 less damage, and lowering Strength to 10 is another 2 less damage and a lot less weight you can carry. You will either have to leave a lot of loot behind, make a lot of trips to a merchant to sell stuff, or learn to live with being encumbered when you are not buffed. Even 14 strength is somewhat limiting on how much you can carry.
